Authors:
Ana Paula Gelli de Faria, Julian Aguirres-Santoro, Gregory
K. Brown, TÃ¢nia Wendt
Title:
Morphological and Molecular Evidence of Monophyly in Aechmea
subgenus Macrochordion (Bromeliaceae: Bromelioideae)
Keywords:
Atlantic Forest, phylogeny, combined data, matK,
psbA-trnH, trnL-trnF
Abstract:
Generic and infrageneric delimitation in Bromeliaceae is
poorly understood, especially in Aechmea, and recent phylogenetic
studies have focused on discovery of monophyletic lineages. Aechmea
subgenus Macrochordion includes six taxa, and is entirely restricted to
the Brazilian Atlantic Forest, except for A. bromeliifolia, which occurs
from Central America to Argentina. In order to assess the monophyly of
Macrochordion and gain a better understanding of interspecific
evolutionary relationships within the subgenus, we carried out
phylogenetic analyses using parsimony and bayesian approaches, based on
combined morphological and molecular data. The results supported the
monophyly of Macrochordion as well as a sister relationship with
Brazilian species of Aechmea subgenera Pothuava and Chevaliera. Of the
characters used to circumscribe Macrochordion in past classifications,
only the unarmed sepals were found to be synapomorphic for the subgenus.
Relationships within Macrochordion are discussed in the context of
morphological and biogeographical data and provide a framework for
future research at a finer geographic scale and with population level
sampling.
